awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Genomics and AI-based biological effect benchmark development for functional ingredients
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to improve the consistency of functional food and beverage and dietary supplements (FFBDS).  Functional ingredients are ingredients that have benefits beyond normal nutrition, such as curcumin (turmeric), green tea, and cranberry extract. Currently FFBDS companies face challenges in sourcing functional ingredients that are consistent in their quality from batch-to-batch. The testing methods measure only the ingredient quantity and not quality. This project advances a technology to measure the effectiveness of these functional ingredients.  This information enables FFBDS manufacturers to provide clarity, trust, and ease to the process of purchasing functional products. Furthermore, this can also be used to identify the specific health benefits and develop personalized nutrition products. In addition, the data can provide traceability and information for sustainable farming, harvesting, extracting, and manufacturing practices.

The proposed project will develop biological effect benchmarks for the pure form of functional ingredients, starting with turmeric, using commercially available human cells, genomics, and artificial intelligence technologies.  The project will develop a test to measures a compound's biological effectiveness compared to that of the benchmark. The system will generate a biological effect score of the ingredient, a list of key genes affected, and a description of the relevance of these genes on human health. The system will be developed for high-throughput, cost-effective operation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project created a solution for standardization of the biological effect of botanical ingredients that are commonly used in dietary supplements, functional beverages, and skin care products. The overall goal is to develop an affordable and efficient way to test botanical ingredients for their biological effect for every batch and provide a comprehensive report about an ingredient’s biological effect and contaminant effect to the customer. Currently, chemical analytical methods such as high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) are the only methods used for quality assurance (QA). While analytical tests provide content information for the active molecule present in the ingredient and may work well as a proxy for biological effect for synthetic molecules, analytical tools are inadequate for assuring the biological effect of botanical ingredients. Botanical ingredients pose a unique challenge: they differ from batch-to-batch due to variations in plant strains, harvest times, regional climate changes, soil conditions, extraction methods, and more. Currently, there are no methods available to the industry that solve this problem in a cost and time-efficient manner. To accomplish this, genomics and artificial intelligence (AI) methods were used to create benchmark biological effect tests and quality standardization. The Phase I study created a blueprint for developing benchmark tests for other botanical ingredients in the future.

 

In order to develop this technology, one botanical, turmeric, was selected as a prototypical ingredient to optimize the methods and protocols. Turmeric was used because of its popularity in the consumer market and due to the vast amount of scientific information available for turmeric. Additionally, benchmarks for contaminants like LPS (protein of the bacterium E. Coli) and lead (Pb) were also developed. Pure grade turmeric containing 100% curcumin, the active ingredient of turmeric, was used to develop the biological effect benchmark. To test the technology, commercially available dietary supplements that contained only turmeric were purchased from a major online retailer and were compared against this benchmark. To develop the benchmark, commercially available human cells were treated with these different turmeric with or without contaminants, and gene expression changes in 20,000+ human genes were analyzed. Gene expression changes were used as a measure of the biological effect. Different cellular pathways and human health and wellness conditions affected by these pure-grade, commercial, non-contaminated or contaminated turmeric samples were identified.

A benchmark biological effect score was attributed to the pure grade turmeric and an AI-based biological score predictor software technology was developed to score the effectiveness of each of the commercial turmeric relative to the benchmark. Similar contaminant effect score was attributed to LPS along with contaminant predictor software. Comparison between benchmark and some commercial turmeric samples showed greater similarity and thus a higher score on biological effect score predictor while others showed very little similarity with and a lower score on the score predictor suggesting quality issues. Similarly samples that were artificially contaminated with LPS, showed similar to turmeric that was mixed with the contaminant.

 

Importantly, through this award, Canomiks successfully developed proprietary genomics and AI methods to reduce the cost and time of the processes needed to develop the benchmark and to test a commercial botanical sample. Finally, using turmeric as a prototypical botanical ingredient and LPS and Pb as prototypical contaminants, Canomiks was able to  de-risk the technology by identifying any product development challenges laying the foundation for benchmark  development for other botanical ingredients in the future.

 

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2024
Modified by: Leena Pradhan-Nabzdyk
